text:
In November, I wrote about how Amazon's search algorithm was spitting out Louis Farrakhan's anti-Semitic books in response to reasonable queries about Jews and blacks:
https://www.tabletmag.com/scroll/275042/amazons-algorithm-has-an-anti-semitism-problem …

This week, they dropped those books. I think they should've just fixed the algorithm.
author: Yair_Rosenberg

text: So I launched my newsletter a couple days ago, and am amazed at how many of you were willing to let me spam your inbox. Thank you all. We might even hit 1,000 subscribers by the end of the week. Those interested can sign up here:

text: Important piece by @bungarsargon on a new bipartisan piece of Israel-related legislation that avoids the pitfalls of previous Republican ones, and ought to get support from both parties.

text: The child of a Holocaust survivor and pogrom refugee is now the president of America's top university. It's a remarkable fact that goes almost unremarked upon. And it's a reminder of the America most Jews believe in, because we've seen it and want it for more people.
author: Yair_Rosenberg

text: Currently drafting the inaugural edition of my newsletter. Sign up now to make sure you don't miss it! http://yair.substack.com

text: I'm starting a newsletter! Subscribe and you'll get links to all my articles; thoughts and stories too complex for Twitter but too short for a full feature; cutting room material from my reporting; and Q&A with readers and critics. Also, some bonus stuff! http://yair.substack.com

text: The Goebbels Gap: the amount of time between something bad happening in the world, and someone finding a way to blame the Jews for it.
author: Yair_Rosenberg

text: This blatantly anti-Semitic tweet blaming the New Zealand shooting on the Jews is still up, as is the account that tweeted it. Basically, you can substitute "Israel" for "Jews" and get away with anything anti-Semitic, it seems.
author: Yair_Rosenberg

text: <insert 'it's happening' gif>

text: Dual loyalty accusations insinuate that a person's loyalty to another group takes precedence over their loyalty to their own country. That's exactly what this is. If you're saying he's suggesting they don't even have loyalty to America, well, that just makes it worse.
author: Yair_Rosenberg

text: Dual loyalty smears are toxic and wrong whether they are directed at Jews, Muslims, or anyone else. This is not hard.
author: Yair_Rosenberg

text: In any case, if you want to understand where Bennett and Shaked come from, and why they pose a credible hard-right threat next Israeli election, if not necessarily this one, I have a deep dive for you:
author: Yair_Rosenberg

text: I mean, that is obvious. Their absolute disdain for basic diplomacy is one of their many faults. Though I'd place West bank annexation atop that list.
author: Yair_Rosenberg

text: I presume because they are trying to imitate the visual style of Western perfume commercials that also air in Israel. Bennett's people have always had the most well-produced online ads, but they've never quite translated into votes.
author: Yair_Rosenberg

text: Yes, she and Bennett couldn't care less about how this looks to non-Hebrew speakers, though that's the least of the reasons they are a disaster. Journalists do have an obligation to not just report the English word, though, and actually explain it isn't an endorsement of fascism.
author: Yair_Rosenberg

text: One has to actually know the policy she's talking about to understand what it means:
author: Yair_Rosenberg

text: The real significance of this ad is that Naftali Bennett and Shaked's much-hyped "New Right" party is floundering in the polls and they are desperately trying to grab the attention of right-wing voters with this stunt. Guess we'll see if it works.
author: Yair_Rosenberg

text: For those wondering what this troll ad means in English: Shaked's party wants to subordinate the Israeli judiciary to parliament. The left calls this fascism, and she is mocking them, saying that her policy is actually more democratic (since it puts parliament over the courts).
author: Yair_Rosenberg

text: It's a bad troll. They're saying that what they want is more democracy (subordinating the judiciary to the Knesset, specifically), while the left labels this fascism. That is, what the left calls fascism "smells like" democracy to them.
author: Yair_Rosenberg

text: Wait, this is a thing?
author: Yair_Rosenberg

text:
We just got our first rating on @goodreads: 5 stars!
https://www.goodreads.com/book/show/44292015-the-unofficial-muggle-megillah …
author: Yair_Rosenberg

text: At the time, she was just the third woman in the world to be elected prime minister of her country
author: Yair_Rosenberg

text: White supremacists want people to hate minorities. So they impersonate minorities on Twitter and say hateful things, to try and get people to hate them. This has been going on for years. We made a bot to expose these accounts, and Twitter suspended *it*: https://www.nytimes.com/2017/12/27/opinion/digital-nazi-hunter-trump.html …
author: Yair_Rosenberg

text:
Here's a white supremacist impersonating a "pro-Israel" Jew on Twitter, in order to spread obvious anti-Semitic content.

A reminder that this sort of insidious trash is rife on this platform, and Twitter doesn't have the capability or cultural competency to even recognize it.
author: Yair_Rosenberg

text: There are many ways to express how messed up our current administration is, and one of them is this: Our country is governed by a manchild who throws a tantrum when his favorite Islamophobic show isn't on.
author: Yair_Rosenberg

text: For sure. I think one of the important storylines to watch this election (and I hope that there are some academics already studying it) is the connection or lack thereof between Twitter and real life in terms of discourse around the candidates.
author: Yair_Rosenberg

text: My life would be so much easier if I just went around earnestly talking about how "As a Jew I think Israel does control everything and is behind all the wars." I blame my parents for raising me with a sense of ethics. Thanks parents.
author: Yair_Rosenberg

text: Yes, very much so. Casualties of 280 characters.
author: Yair_Rosenberg

text: It actually makes sense! She's just one member of the House of Representatives, and has never run in a higher profile race (like Beto). It's all the Twitter attention she gets that's out of whack.
author: Yair_Rosenberg

text: I'm just awed by the shamelessness of the grift at this point.
author: Yair_Rosenberg

text: Seems pretty clear that there's lots of enthusiasm for Bernie, both IRL and on this platform, no? (There's just also a strong anti-Bernie contingent, thanks t0 2016.) Tulsi seems less salient everywhere.
author: Yair_Rosenberg

text: This is your periodic reminder that Gazans are trapped between Hamas—a terrorist organization that doesn't let them vote and violently suppresses any dissent from their messianic war to destroy Israel—and the Israeli blockade meant to combat Hamas, but which ensnares all Gazans.
author: Yair_Rosenberg

text: Without fanfare or much media attention, ordinary Gazans have been bravely protesting against Hamas for days. In response, Hamas has dispersed their demonstrations with gunfire and detained hundreds of them. They also beat up journalists reporting on it. (https://www.haaretz.com/middle-east-news/palestinians/.premium-hamas-detains-hundreds-after-violently-suppressing-gaza-s-revolt-of-the-hungry-1.7025221 …)
author: Yair_Rosenberg

text: Wow, so Beto's campaign withheld its launch fundraising numbers, giving reporters and observers the impression that they were underwhelming, only to release them and top every other candidate. Well played.
author: Yair_Rosenberg

text: No.
author: Yair_Rosenberg

text: Omar's section on Israel in this piece is quite reasonable and far better and less fraught than her off-the-cuff tweets on the subject. Which suggests, among other things, that perhaps we're poorly served by reducing issues like the Israeli-Palestinian conflict to 280 characters.
author: Yair_Rosenberg

text: Purim begins this Wednesday night, which means you're running out of time to order my dad's Muggle Megillah in time for the holiday! Get yours today with free Prime shipping: http://amzn.to/2XyAC7G
author: Yair_Rosenberg

text: There's exactly one appropriate response to Bernie's injury, and that's to wish him a speedy recovery.
author: Yair_Rosenberg

text: If we arbitrarily restrict our focus on a bigotry to just one country or community, we will miss all the ways it jumps from one place to another and infects different communities in different ways. This stuff is rarely contained, and it is rarely just someone else's problem.
author: Yair_Rosenberg

text: The Protocols of the Elders of Zion, arguably the most influential anti-Semitic tract, originated in Russia, then jumped to Europe, US & Middle East. Especially in the internet age, we need to understand bigotry—from anti-Semitism to white supremacy—as a transnational phenomenon.
author: Yair_Rosenberg

text: Cannot think of a more fitting way to give in response to this tragedy
author: Yair_Rosenberg

text: You misspelled "racist"
author: Yair_Rosenberg

text: You get a million notifications, so I figured that one just zipped by. I was just clarifying my thinking, not trying to imply something about yours, but figured it best to make it explicit.
author: Yair_Rosenberg

text: You seem to have missed the tweet right after that one:
author: Yair_Rosenberg

text: (And to be clear, I think we mostly agree on this, so I apologize for wasting your time arguing around the edges. Don't want to imply things about your views you do not hold.)
author: Yair_Rosenberg

text: As I said, depending which countries one picks, one will find Jews or Muslims more discriminated against in the media. US/UK: Muslims. Greece/Poland/Hungary: Jews. And so on. I think we are foolish if we draw arbitrary frames rather than seeing these bigotries as global menaces.
author: Yair_Rosenberg

text: You suggested no BBC presenter would ever respond to an anti-Semitic attack by pointing to Israel. I pointed out that happened not just on the BBC, but in many other places besides. You claimed it is rare and always condemned. I proved otherwise. You say I whatabouted. I did not.
author: Yair_Rosenberg

text: Ah, got it. Well, on that, we are entirely in agreement. It's long past time the way we talked about this stuff started to change.
author: Yair_Rosenberg

text: We're not arguing over white nationalists versus Muslim extremists. If you read the thread, we're discussing the treatment of anti-Semitism around the world and anti-Muslim prejudice around the world. I completely agree with your tweet, but it's not what's at issue.
author: Yair_Rosenberg

text: White nationalism is a global phenomenon that jumps from place to place and spreads influence via the internet. Anti-Semitism has been a transnational phenomenon like that for centuries. The Protocols went from Russia to Europe to US to Middle East. Maybe expand your frames.
author: Yair_Rosenberg

text: One would have to go country-by-country. Very different situations in say, United States & Eastern Europe (where they are publishing front page guides to "identifying Jews" in Poland). I also think fighting over who's the bigger bigot is a distraction from fighting the bigots.
author: Yair_Rosenberg

text: I think it's a dumb argument too. That's why I keep saying that the important thing is to call this stuff out no matter who it targets. I will always do so, whether it's done to Muslims, Jews, or other minorities that get held collectively accountable for the acts of individuals.
author: Yair_Rosenberg

text:
I even did a little thread venting about this 10 days ago: https://twitter.com/Yair_Rosenberg/status/1103748983351062529 …

It's a constant drumbeat, and almost never called out by the allies of those who do it. Which is why it keeps getting worse.
author: Yair_Rosenberg

text: Every time I report on an anti-Semitism story anywhere in the world, I get responses asking whether I condemn Netanyahu/the Zionists. It's a default reply on this platform in particular. That you seem to think this is rare or universally condemned suggests a lack of familiarity.
author: Yair_Rosenberg

text: I have been reporting on this sort of anti-Semitism for years. Most of it goes entirely unreported and ignored by mainstream outlets. You didn't even remember this story when you tweeted as though it never happened. Think about why that is. It's an exception that proves the rule.
author: Yair_Rosenberg

text:
Actually, he was cleared and faced no consequences: https://amp.theguardian.com/media/2016/jun/16/bbcs-charlie-hebdo-interview-cleared-over-anti-semitic-complaints …

It's time to stop minimizing this stuff and start fighting it, or it will keep happening.
author: Yair_Rosenberg

text: This is true of black folks, too, of course. Majority cultures often construct minorities as collectively accountable for anything any member does -- something that is never done to the majority culture. This impacts blacks, Jews, Muslims, and many others.
author: Yair_Rosenberg

text: Exactly. I was thinking that and ran out of characters. Majority cultures often construct minorities as collectively accountable for anything any member does -- something that is never done to the majority culture. This impacts blacks, Jews, Muslims, and many others.
author: Yair_Rosenberg

text: Muslims everywhere are not complicit in whatever any Muslim or group of Muslims may do. Jews everywhere are not complicit in whatever any Jew or group of Jews may do. If you accept this thinking for either of them, you are complicit in bigotry that targets them. It's that simple.
author: Yair_Rosenberg

text:
This victim-blaming happens to Jews all the time in the wake of anti-Semitic attacks, including on the BBC:
https://www.tabletmag.com/scroll/188231/bbc-anchor-suggests-french-jews-to-blame-for-palestinian-suffering …
https://www.tabletmag.com/scroll/189064/swedish-public-radio-asks-are-jews-responsible-for-anti-semitism …
It's wrong when done to Muslims, and wrong when done to Jews. I hope we can start to call it out no matter who is targeted.
author: Yair_Rosenberg

text:
Here's Swedish public radio doing it to Jews: https://www.tabletmag.com/scroll/189064/swedish-public-radio-asks-are-jews-responsible-for-anti-semitism …
(I could go on)
author: Yair_Rosenberg

text:
This happens to Jews all the time in the wake of anti-Semitic attacks, including on the BBC: 
https://www.tabletmag.com/scroll/188231/bbc-anchor-suggests-french-jews-to-blame-for-palestinian-suffering …

It's wrong when done to Muslims, and wrong when done to Jews. I hope we can start to call it out no matter who it's targeting.
author: Yair_Rosenberg

text: It's good to see the internet was used responsibly while I was gone for shabbat.
author: Yair_Rosenberg

text: It is unfashionable to talk about "evil," but there is no other word to describe what just happened in New Zealand. A reminder that Twitter is often the worst place to be at a time like this, and the best place to be is with those in pain. Be there for your Muslim friends.
author: Yair_Rosenberg

text: :D
author: Yair_Rosenberg

text:
Interested readers are welcome to Google Salazar and learn more, and of course, to read my story on her, which I think holds up quite well: https://www.tabletmag.com/jewish-news-and-politics/270095/julia-salazar-arrested-2011 …
And now you go back behind the block, where intellectually dishonest folks belong in my feed. Take care!
author: Yair_Rosenberg

text: Hi! You were not blocked for anything to do with Israel; we've never even discussed it. You were blocked because you smeared my outlet and me for doing journalism (with audio recordings to back it up) about NY state senator Julia Salazar. You lied then and you're lying now.
author: Yair_Rosenberg

text: One of my favorite features on this web site is when you find a good tweet, and are about to write what you think is a witty reply, only to discover that @Popehat is already there and blew you out of the water.
author: Yair_Rosenberg

text: These days, no one announces their VP pick until they win the nomination (though there was a desperate attempt late in the 2016 GOP primary that failed). Of course, Biden could pick Abrams after winning, but if they started out together...
author: Yair_Rosenberg

text: This will never happen, but if Biden just launched his campaign with Abrams there as his VP pick from the start, they'd sweep every primary.
author: Yair_Rosenberg

text: You are far too kind, Yashar.
author: Yair_Rosenberg

text:
"He said 'the Rothschild family' were 'behind a lot of the neo-liberal influence in the UK and US'.

'And you only have to Google them to look at this - ever since they funded the Napoleonic wars and made enormous profits just over 200 year ago.'"
author: Yair_Rosenberg

text: .@lucianaberger, a Jewish member of Britain's parliament, quit her own Labour party in protest of it being "institutionally anti-Semitic." The local Labour party meeting to find someone to replace her was chaired by…an anti-Semite who rants about Rothschilds. Can't make this up.
author: Yair_Rosenberg

text: Glad to hear it! If she wants to review it on Amazon, we'd love to read her thoughts.
author: Yair_Rosenberg

text: Sympathy for the people of Tel Aviv and the people of Gaza are not mutually exclusive. The terrorists, meanwhile, deserve no sympathy or quarter.
author: Yair_Rosenberg

text: They "elected" Hamas over a decade ago. They've never been allowed to vote since and kick them out. Many of the people in Gaza now, especially young people, had absolutely nothing to do with that vote, yet suffer its consequences every day. They deserve better.
author: Yair_Rosenberg

text: Today, the people of Gaza had their protest against Hamas misrule suppressed by gunfire. Tonight, thanks to terrorists firing rockets at Israeli population centers from Gaza, they go to sleep waiting for Israel to retaliate. They deserve our sympathy and they deserve better.
author: Yair_Rosenberg

text: True story: Amazon once interpolated a page from a Christian book about the crucifixion into an otherwise pristine copy of the Haggadah. That was awkward.
author: Yair_Rosenberg

text: Ugh, that's terrible. We haven't heard of any issues like that, but it happened once with one of the Hogwarts Haggadahs. Amazon prints them so this is their error and you should absolutely demand a new copy. They're usually good about that.
author: Yair_Rosenberg

text: I'm glad you like it! It means "will illuminate" or "will light up."
author: Yair_Rosenberg

text: I am lucky to have readers who both read me and challenge me. Knowing that Palestinians read my work on Israel/Palestine has unquestionably made it better, and made me try harder to capture the full nuances of this extremely difficult story.
author: Yair_Rosenberg

text: Today, Hamas dispersed Gazans protesting their misgovernance with gunfire. You can be critical of Israel's policy toward Gaza without whitewashing Hamas and its oppression of Gaza's people or its genocidal ambitions towards Israel. Doing the first has nothing to do w/ the second.
author: Yair_Rosenberg

text: To me, they are the same yearning! I support a Palestinian state precisely because I know what a state has meant to the Jewish people.
author: Yair_Rosenberg

text:
A reminder that Israel/Palestine Twitter is full of false dichotomies: if you're pro-Israel, you must be anti-Palestinian; if you're pro-Palestinian, you must be anti-Israel; being critical of Israel's Gaza policy means supporting the genocidal Hamas. Etc.

Don't fall for them.
author: Yair_Rosenberg

text: Yeah, good luck with that.
author: Yair_Rosenberg

text: (((Purim)))
author: Yair_Rosenberg

text: It confuses me that some people think "don't fire rockets at innocent civilians" somehow means "everything Israel does in Gaza is good." Those look like totally different sentences to me & totally different claims, but guess I'm not as smart as various Twitter keyboard warriors.
author: Yair_Rosenberg

text: Seems pretty straightforward when you put it in nice English sentences like that. No so hard! More people should try it.
author: Yair_Rosenberg

text: I don't think we disagree, to be clear!
author: Yair_Rosenberg

text:
If you're protesting Israel's blockade of Gaza by defending either the firing of rockets at random Israeli civilians or Hamas, an internationally-recognized terrorist group explicitly committed to Jewish genocide, you're doing it wrong. 

The first in no way entails the second.
author: Yair_Rosenberg

text: Because, after Israel pulled all its settlements and soldiers out of Gaza in 2005, the place was taken over by Hamas, an internationally recognized terrorist organization explicitly committed to Jewish genocide in its charter. Which now fires the rockets.
author: Yair_Rosenberg

text: One fun fact about Israel is that the movie theaters have bomb shelters because the neighbors like to fire rockets indiscriminately at Israeli civilians on occasion.
author: Yair_Rosenberg

text: Israel in one tweet
author: Yair_Rosenberg

text: Tel Aviv right now
author: Yair_Rosenberg

text: For those who missed it, a little dive into the weird Twitter underbelly of bots and efforts to artificially boost particular sentiments and ideas:
author: Yair_Rosenberg

text:
No, saying a person with a Jewish name only has the opinions they do because they were paid to have them by other Jews is anti-Semitic.

The other stuff would just be dumb.
author: Yair_Rosenberg

text: That sounds like a reasonable argument to me, couched in very reasonable language. Plenty of people would disagree with it (I would), but I sure wouldn't call that anti-Semitic.
author: Yair_Rosenberg

text: Seth is taking it in stride but this is an ugly and common form of anti-Semitic abuse on Twitter that deserves spelling out: if you attack a random Jewish journalist and insinuate they are working for Israel or the Israel lobby, you are an anti-Semite. Block any user who does it.
author: Yair_Rosenberg

text: It was order 63 that was the real doozie though.
author: Yair_Rosenberg

text: It's amazing how the conspiracy theory that Jews control the media coexists with this trash, but then, that's why they call it a conspiracy theory.
author: Yair_Rosenberg

text: Only in Israel can you run an ad featuring a Jewish politician standing next to a giant pile of money and it genuinely is not anti-Semitic.
author: Yair_Rosenberg

text: One thing Twitter getting rid of the retweet and like counters will do is disincentivize this sort of gaming of the system, whereby fake accounts retweet stuff to give it the false appearance of virality and popularity. If there are no counters, then there's no point.
author: Yair_Rosenberg

text: My curiosity here is whether this botnet is actually Palestinians at all, or if it's an outside actor that's just using the Palestinian issue as a wedge issue on social media.
author: Yair_Rosenberg

text: Among other things, the Palestine botnet seems very interested in boosting this @mattyglesias tweet and this @BuzzFeedNews op-ed. Dozens of accounts with identical retweets like these.
author: Yair_Rosenberg

text: I found these fake folks because they all replied almost at once to a single tweet of mine about Omar. Not great subterfuge, I have to say.
author: Yair_Rosenberg

text: Right now, this pro-Palestine botnet is defending Ilhan Omar (unhelpfully, their defense consists of insisting Jews are in fact loyal to Israel) and Asa Winstanley, a blogger suspended by the UK Labour party for anti-Semitism. He's the bearded guy whose pic they keep sharing.
author: Yair_Rosenberg

text: A few more of the bots. Not going to screencap them all, but you get the picture.
author: Yair_Rosenberg

text: Some of these bots have male avatars. Some have female avatars. Some have cat avatars. Some say they're in Gaza. Some say they're in Turkey. Some say they're in Europe. Some say they're in Minnesota.
author: Yair_Rosenberg

text: I just got flooded by tweets from what appears to be a pretty extensive pro-Palestine network of bots. Even though many of the accounts have different names and locations and even genders, they all have the same retweets and memes. Fascinating. Wonder who's behind it.
author: Yair_Rosenberg

text: Oh, I know this one! The Jewish country, and only the Jewish country.
author: Yair_Rosenberg

text: A lot of people spent a lot of time claiming Jewish people were hearing things in Omar's language that weren't there. Maybe they can now explain that to Omar's defenders, who heard the exact same anti-Semitic canard (and agreed with it).
author: Yair_Rosenberg

text: See, you just responded to a tweet about people saying Jews aren't loyal to America (an anti-Semitic canard) by pivoting to Israel, as though that justifies the anti-Semitism in America. Thank you for helpfully demonstrating how the anti-Semitic deflection to Israel works.
author: Yair_Rosenberg

text:
While defending Omar on Facebook, Bernie Sanders's deputy press secretary said, "Do you not think that the American government and American Jewish community has a dual allegiance to the State of Israel?" 

Which shows that she knew EXACTLY what Omar meant. Let's stop pretending.
author: Yair_Rosenberg

text:
cc: Trump

and also all those idiots on this hell site who like to blame the Jews for Trump
author: Yair_Rosenberg

text: That is the previous appeal that was ruled on by a state attorney in *January*. Look at the date. It was appealed to the prosecutor general, who just made this new ruling (which was much worse than the earlier one, which condemned the statement as hateful, but didn't prosecute).
author: Yair_Rosenberg

text:
"At the concert, the rapper wished Muslims a happy Eid al-Fitr holiday and acknowledged Christian listeners. He did not mention Israel.

On June 10, 2018, five days before the concert, Kholardi wrote on Twitter 'f—ing Jews are so corrupt.'"
https://www.jta.org/quick-reads/norwegian-rapper-who-cursed-jews-during-performance-was-criticizing-israel-prosecutors-say …
author: Yair_Rosenberg

text:
I hope the folks who are very vocal that criticism of Israel is not anti-Semitism will be loudly protesting against Norway now, to make clear that this is not acceptable and taints legitimate criticism of Israel.

Unless, of course, they don't really care about anti-Semitism?
author: Yair_Rosenberg

text: There is basically nothing you can say or do against Jews that will not be defended by anti-Semites as mere "criticism of Israel." And this is now official state policy in a major European country, which will only encourage more bigots to go after Jews there.
author: Yair_Rosenberg

text: It sounds like you didn't read the tweet. Try again.
author: Yair_Rosenberg

text:
How anti-Zionism is used to legitimize anti-Semitism:

A rapper at a festival in Oslo asked if there were any Jews in the crowd, then said "f— Jews."

Norway's attorney general just ruled that this wasn't hate speech, b/c it could be "criticism of Israel."
author: Yair_Rosenberg

text: There's less of a "generational divide" among Democrats than there is a new generation with its own new divides
author: Yair_Rosenberg

text: The big reveal at the end is that the whole story is actually the undercover teen's college essay about how he helped the FBI take down an SAT scam ring. And then he doesn't get in.
author: Yair_Rosenberg
